Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: The structure of the ASL lexicon: experimental and statistical evidence from a large lexical database (ASL-LEX)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will record and study the properties of lexical forms in American Sign Language. Almost everything we know about human language comes from the study of spoken languages. However, only by studying sign languages is it possible to discover which linguistic rules and constraints are universal to all human languages and which depend on the particular properties of an individual language. By studying sign languages researchers can uncover language patterns that are tied to the nature of the articulators (i.e., the hands vs. the vocal tract) or that are linked to the specific way a language is perceived (i.e., visually vs. auditorally). Researchers can also uncover language patterns that result from properties that systematically vary between spoken and signed languages, such as the high prevalence of iconic forms (words that resemble what they mean) in sign languages. Psychological and linguistic research on spoken languages has relied on lexical databases--repositories of information about the words of a language--to identify factors that influence how words are comprehended and produced, to understand how words are organized and structured in the mind and brain (in our "mental lexicon"), and to discover the linguistic patterns that are present in languages. Unfortunately however, there is currently no comparably large lexical database for American Sign Language (ASL), the sign language used by deaf and hearing people in the United States.

A primary aim of this project is to create a large, searchable, and publically available database of approximately 2,500 ASL signs. The database (called ASL-LEX) will contain the following information for each sign: subjective frequency-of-use ratings, iconicity ratings from both deaf signers and hearing non-signers, sign duration measures, lexical category information (e.g., noun, verb, etc.), and codes for sign-based phonological features (e.g., location, handshape, movement) that can be used to calculate whether the form of a sign is relatively common (has many form 'neighbors') or relatively unique (has few 'neighbors'). A second aim is to use ASL-LEX to conduct the first quantitative analysis of the ASL lexicon in order to uncover regularities in the way that phonological features appear (or do not appear) in ASL signs and how these patterns are influenced by sign properties such as frequency and iconicity. A third aim is to conduct experiments to determine the psychological reality of these phonological patterns (e.g., do signers unconsciously know which patterns are common and which are rare?) and to discover how phonological and lexical properties impact how quickly a sign is recognized (using a novel sign recognition technique) and produced (using a picture-naming task). Data from these experiments and related materials (e.g. picture stimuli) will be made available to the public through ASL-LEX. These materials constitute essential tools that will allow scientists and educators to create well-controlled ASL stimuli for use in research and the classroom. ASL-LEX can also be used by educators and early intervention specialists to develop benchmarks for assessing vocabulary development in signing children, (e.g., do children know the most frequent signs?) and to support literacy development (e.g., to find sign-based "rhymes"). A parallel aim of the project is to increase the representation of deaf people in science by including deaf researchers on the project and by providing an accessible environment for deaf students to gain training and research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While words are the basic building blocks of language, words themselves are built from even smaller linguistic units. In spoken languages, words are composed of basic units of sound. Each spoken language has its own unique set of sounds and rules for how those sounds can be combined. In English, for example, words can begin with the sequences /bl/ and /tr/ but not /bn/ (BLICK but not BNICK). Some sound sequences appear to be of intermediate “goodness”: even though words can start with either /bl/ and /dw/ (e.g, dwarf, dwindle), English speakers typically feel that /bl/ sounds better than /dw/. Research has also shown that different types of words tend to have different sound sequences: words that are used frequently often have different sequences than words that are used less often and nouns tend to have different sequences of sounds than verbs.

In signed languages, signs are also composed of smaller units: handshapes which are made in particular locations with particular motions. While each sign language has its own unique set of handshapes, locations, and motions, relatively little is known about the extent to which there are rules on how these elements can combine to form signs. The purpose of this project was to study the phonological patterns of American Sign Language (ASL). In particular, we used statistical techniques to determine what patterns exist in ASL and whether signers mentally encode these patterns.

Making use of a new database of ASL that our team created, we searched the ASL lexicon for patterns in how handshapes, locations, and movements combine. In contrast to sounds in spoken languages, we found that basic sign elements combine with each other at approximately the same rate. That is, individual handshapes, locations, and movements appear in signs with each other with roughly equal frequency. This was true every way we looked the signs: signs that are used frequently and signs that are used less frequently, signs that are highly iconic (that look like their meaning) and signs that are less iconic, and signs from different parts of speech (nouns vs. verbs).

The difference in the way phonological elements combine in spoken and signed languages may be due to a fundamental difference in how they are produced and perceived. While sounds in words unfold one after each other in a sequence (in ‘blue’, /b/ is produced before /l/, etc.), handshapes, locations, and motions are all produced simultaneously in a sign—a handshape can’t be produced without producing it a particular location; a motion can’t be produced without a handshape. Our results suggest that it may be easy for combination patterns to develop when phonological elements unfold sequentially and are harder to develop when phonological elements are produced simultaneously.

To explore what signers mentally encode about ASL phonological patterns, we conducted a ‘signlikeness’ judgment study. This is the first time, to our knowledge, that a study like this has been conducted in a sign language. In this experiment, we created new signs that look like ASL signs and asked native deaf signers to judge how plausible they are as signs of ASL. When studies like this are conducted with English participants and items, novel words like BLICK are rated better than words like DWICK and BNICK, mirroring the frequency of /bl/, /dw/ and /bn/ in the language. We found that signers’ judgments were influenced by the basic phonological elements of the novel signs. For example, two-handed novel signs with the same handshape performing the same movement were rated as less good/signlike than two-handed novel signs where each hand has a different handshape. We also found that novel signs that resemble many existing signs were rated better than novel signs resembling few existing signs. From this we infer that signers mentally encode the phonological patterns present in ASL and use these patterns (and similarity to existing signs) to judge how much a new sign looks like an ASL sign.

At the same time, we found that many phonological elements like location and motion did not seem to play a role in these judgments. We are uncertain of why this may be. It may be the case that there are better ways to make novel signs and that we may be able to observe more influences with better stimuli. It may also be the case that signers judged the novel signs based on combinations of elements that we did not consider.

All together, these studies shed light on the phonological patterns of American Sign Language and help uncover what signers unconsciously know about these patterns. They also point the way towards a deeper understanding of what the basic properties are of sign phonology and new ways to study them.
